Of common-place, the literary water,</br>Take quantum suff., and, for your chief ingredient,</br>Some high-born Count's, or wealthy Baron's daughter;</br>A brace of lovers is, at least, expedient,</br>And one, by rule, must make the Lady lenient;</br>Be sure my Lord's a most unnatural father;</br>A maiden-aunt besides you'll find convenient;</br>Mix them much mawkish sentiment together,</br>In every sort of scene, and every kind of weather.

Of parchments, bravos, plots and blood, be lavish;</br>And let, to prove how fierce the lady's honour,</br>The hated lover every thing but ravish;</br>To heap more terrible imbroglios on her,</br>Let father, aunts, and uncles all disown her;</br>When plagued enough, to save her, let, by chance,</br>Some grisly ghost compassion take upon her;</br>Then fix your scene in Italy or France,</br>And dub the Monster's birth a Novel or Romance.</br>
